DataElement.preferredName: Tumor To Normal Control Tissue DNA Distance Category
DataElement.preferredDefinition: Text term to signify the distance between the tumor tissue and the normal control tissue that was procured for matching normal DNA.

DataElementConcept.preferredName: Tumor To Normal Control Tissue Distance
DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: A benign or malignant tissue growth resulting from uncontrolled cell proliferation.  Benign neoplastic cells resemble normal cells without exhibiting significant cytologic atypia, while malignant cells exhibit overt signs such as dysplastic features, atypical mitotic figures, necrosis, nuclear pleomorphism, and anaplasia.  Representative examples of benign neoplasms include papillomas, cystadenomas, and lipomas; malignant neoplasms include carcinomas, sarcomas, lymphomas, and leukemias._Used as a function word to indicate direction, purpose, or movement._The act of directing or determining; regulation or maintenance of a function or action; a relation of constraint of one entity (thing or person or group) by another._An anatomical structure consisting of similarly specialized cells and intercellular matrix, aggregated according to genetically determined spatial relationships, performing a specific function._the space between two objects or points.

ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: A benign or malignant tissue growth resulting from uncontrolled cell proliferation. Benign neoplastic cells resemble normal cells without exhibiting significant cytologic atypia, while malignant cells exhibit overt signs such as dysplastic features, atypical mitotic figures, necrosis, nuclear pleomorphism, and anaplasia. Representative examples of benign neoplasms include papillomas, cystadenomas, and lipomas; malignant neoplasms include carcinomas, sarcomas, lymphomas, and leukemias.:Used as a function word to indicate direction, purpose, or movement.:The act of directing or determining; regulation or maintenance of a function or action; a relation of constraint of one entity (thing or person or group) by another.:An anatomical structure consisting of similarly specialized cells and intercellular matrix, aggregated according to genetically determined spatial relationships, performing a specific function.

Concepts.definition: A benign or malignant tissue growth resulting from uncontrolled cell proliferation. Benign neoplastic cells resemble normal cells without exhibiting significant cytologic atypia, while malignant cells exhibit overt signs such as dysplastic features, atypical mitotic figures, necrosis, nuclear pleomorphism, and anaplasia. Representative examples of benign neoplasms include papillomas, cystadenomas, and lipomas; malignant neoplasms include carcinomas, sarcomas, lymphomas, and leukemias.
Used as a function word to indicate direction, purpose, or movement.
The act of directing or determining; regulation or maintenance of a function or action; a relation of constraint of one entity (thing or person or group) by another.
An anatomical structure consisting of similarly specialized cells and intercellular matrix, aggregated according to genetically determined spatial relationships, performing a specific function.

Property.preferredDefinition: the space between two objects or points.

Concepts.definition: the space between two objects or points.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: attributes of a patient's laboratory sample, including the source, condition, and fixative.

ValueDomain.preferredName: Neoplasm To Normal DNA Distance Category
ValueDomain.preferredDefinition: A benign or malignant tissue growth resulting from uncontrolled cell proliferation.  Benign neoplastic cells resemble normal cells without exhibiting significant cytologic atypia, while malignant cells exhibit overt signs such as dysplastic features, atypical mitotic figures, necrosis, nuclear pleomorphism, and anaplasia.  Representative examples of benign neoplasms include papillomas, cystadenomas, and lipomas; malignant neoplasms include carcinomas, sarcomas, lymphomas, and leukemias._Used as a function word to indicate direction, purpose, or movement._Being approximately average or within certain limits; conforming with or constituting a norm or standard or level or type or social norm. (NCI)_A long linear double-stranded polymer formed from nucleotides attached to a deoxyribose backbone and found in the nucleus of a cell; associated with the transmission of genetic information._The space separating two objects or points._Category; used informally to mean a class of things.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Distal; situated farthest from a point of attachment or origin, as of a limb or bone; or directed away from the midline or mesial plane of the body.

Concepts.definition: Situated farthest from a point of attachment or origin, as of a limb or bone; or directed away from the midline of the body.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Not known, not observed, not recorded, or refused.

Concepts.definition: Not known, observed, recorded; or reported as unknown by the data contributor.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: attributes of a patient's laboratory sample, including the source, condition, and fixative.

Benign neoplastic cells resemble normal cells without exhibiting significant cytologic atypia, while malignant cells exhibit overt signs such as dysplastic features, atypical mitotic figures, necrosis, nuclear pleomorphism, and anaplasia. Representative examples of benign neoplasms include papillomas, cystadenomas, and lipomas; malignant neoplasms include carcinomas, sarcomas, lymphomas, and leukemias.:Used as a function word to indicate direction, purpose, or movement.:Being approximately average or within certain limits; conforming with or constituting a norm or standard or level or type or social norm. Concepts.definition: A benign or malignant tissue growth resulting from uncontrolled cell proliferation. Benign neoplastic cells resemble normal cells without exhibiting significant cytologic atypia, while malignant cells exhibit overt signs such as dysplastic features, atypical mitotic figures, necrosis, nuclear pleomorphism, and anaplasia. Representative examples of benign neoplasms include papillomas, cystadenomas, and lipomas; malignant neoplasms include carcinomas, sarcomas, lymphomas, and leukemias.
Used as a function word to indicate direction, purpose, or movement.
Being approximately average or within certain limits; conforming with or constituting a norm or standard or level or type or social norm.
A long linear double-stranded polymer formed from nucleotides attached to a deoxyribose backbone and found in the nucleus of a cell; associated with the transmission of genetic information.
The space separating two objects or points.
A grouping of items based on some commonality or by user defined characteristics.

ReferenceDocuments.name: TCGA Additional Information
ReferenceDocuments.description: Adjacent (<= 2cm) normal tissue is not accepted for this tissue type. Unknown normal tissue is not acceptable for this tissue type.

ReferenceDocuments.name: HCMI Question Text
ReferenceDocuments.description: Distance from tumor to normal control tissue (if not blood)
